subject: Re: Spiricom Device
author: LC Duplatt
full_text:
I formally thought "hoax," too, until I found how easy it is for 
ghosts/spirits, etc to use these different devices we have today to 
communicate through.  

It's almost as if the ability to talk to the other side has been 
there the whole time, or better yet, that the other side has been 
communicating with us the whole time, but we simply needed to 
become "awakened" to it...

LC

--- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Bion" <yahoogroups@...> wrote:
>
> When I first listened to the Spiricom samples several years ago, my 
immediate impression was: Hmm, it sounds like someone using 
an "electronic larynx" (speech aid device). This impression was 
strengthened by the observation that the buzzing sound often was even 
modulated by O'Neill's own voice during the dialoges between him 
and "Dr. Mueller"! (Did O'Neill forget to remove the device from his 
throat while talking to his counterpart?)
> 
> And what about the "13 frequencies" that are supposed to be used as 
the "carrier" for the spirit voices? Why aren't they audible in the 
recordings? And why does a mixture of the 13 tones created with 
Audition sound so different from the typical "Spiricom buzz"? - Well, 
if you analyze the frequency spectrum of the buzzing sound (this can 
be done with Audition etc.), you will find a lot of harmonics (peaks 
in the spectrum), and some of these harmonics more or less match the 
13 Spiricom frequencies...
> 
> To me, the entire Spiricom saga produces more questions than 
answers...
>
